title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - Physical Education and Health (2010)
subject: Personal Development

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - Physical Education and Health (2010)

2E477D0D962D475E8E4D778593FF50CB.description: Acts responsibly toward others (e.g. fulfilling one’s commitments during an outdoor activity by bringing the required equipment, looking out for a partner’s safety during an acrogym activity)

7A75852405A240B0B7192970BFB8B3E0.description: Acts responsibly toward him/herself (e.g. acknowledging one’s responsibility if equipment breaks, ensuring personal hygiene, carrying out the required task independently)

91A9C9427F714C5786A1772F7D849826.description: Demonstrates an openness to differences (e.g. agreeing to include a less skilled student, a student from another ethnic group or of the opposite sex on the team)

69A1EF7514E348C2BAA485BF1ECB4B5B.description: Helps others and accepts the help of others, as needed (e.g. helping another student handle equipment, helping in portage during outdoor activities, accepting technical advice)

6A0544D567734629A6BAF6A9DB171729.description: Perseveres in an activity despite difficulties and results in order to surpass him/herself (e.g. trying again after experiencing failure, leaving one’s comfort zone to set a challenge for oneself)

296042B2E3F6409B86376B6FC40C7DB3.description: Demonstrates a certain fighting spirit that is respectful of his/her opponents (e.g. adjusting one’s actions or those of his/her team so as not to humiliate the opponent)

CFAFE96D91F648F1A11B4AC03DE70656.description: Acts fairly in his/her interactions with others (e.g. passing to the player who is in the best position and not to one’s friend, applying the same game rules to everyone when acting as the referee)

F4302DC2538F471EB748E92E428AEA6D.description: Demonstrates dignity and self-control, regardless of the physical activity involved (e.g. controlling his/her emotions)

CD506E09631645D09FB8471A55505BE5.description: Appreciates successful moves and achievements of partners and opponents (e.g. acknowledging good play and victories, congratulating a winning opponent)

0F35036104AF40578E977CBC4BBC91F7.description: Applies rigorously and honestly the rules of the game or the adjustments determined by the teacher (e.g. using the rebound in volleyball, acknowledging that the ball is out during a tennis match, staying on the cross-country trail)

260B91C13F4D43C0806D14BE501F2D4A.description: Manages conflicts independently and peacefully (e.g. talking to a teammate about a problem that arose during game play, using “I” statements)

DDC7F81EC0FB47A4855599F2B4687C68.description: Respects the role of each participant (e.g. respecting the decisions made by the referee, umpire or player-referee, staying out of a partner’s playing area in badminton doubles)

85922EDA51834A15A61E37A7A8DD448B.description: Establishes rules of cooperation with his/her partner(s) (e.g. listening to everyone's ideas, assigning a role to each participant according to his/her strengths)

059F5D7ED8FF401FA994E60C501A7B21.description: Respects equipment and the environment (e.g. not kicking the ball in volleyball, staying on a marked trail, carrying out garbage after an outdoor activity

52401EA17C154F4185010EA8FD311807.description: Shows respect for partners and opponents in his/her words and gestures

CB4A85790F1A4A838E617F2B1C0B4A34.description: Attitudes: Safe participation in physical activity and fair play

6CC0396CE8D548A5BAE2438305350C8C.description: Performs exercises safely, according to the physical activity involved (e.g. aligning the segments and flexing the knees to lift a load, avoiding hyperextensions)

92C87C6E3A854736969F2F901E82AD76.description: Reacts appropriately to potentially dangerous situations (e.g. picking up an object lying on the playing field)

FD3D21A4E4804D65A967CD85302F4AC3.description: Uses simple treatments to prevent or relieve aches and injuries resulting from a physical activity (e.g. stopping the activity, applying ice on a sprain, using a bronchodilator before an activity)

B0C1989E43F140859BA72CAB6A41A878.description: Applies the standards and regulations of sports federations, if applicable (e.g. wearing the required protective equipment)

B6ABBEAB03404C14B3953090134BD292.description: Chooses a partner of the same size and weight as him/herself, if applicable (e.g. in a combat sport, pair up with a student of the same strength)

646282D3556B405CB08B96F6A8DBC1EE.description: Handles heavy equipment or objects safely, either alone or with others (e.g. flexing the knees and hips to lift volleyball posts, holding the load as close to the body as possible)

BDD01FC0895B461C8FC3F44A70B838F7.description: Places, uses and puts away the equipment appropriately (e.g. replacing covers on post anchors)

C342CC2A5D5F4886BBBB5B4B6CC6F008.description: Warms up or cools down in relation to the physical activity involved (e.g. doing dynamic stretching exercises before a sprint)

79C406E85E684CBA8228F2C7243E9D76.description: Wears appropriate clothing for a given physical activity (e.g. appropriate clothing for the weather conditions)

08CA1570EE4C48E697514550A84B5982.description: Skills: Safe participation in physical activity and fair play

4F0AAEE509164CD892C15881508F9137.description: Names the official rules of the game or the rules adapted by the teacher according to the physical activity performed (e.g. naming the rules for serving in badminton doubles, naming a foul in basketball)

6A1EC1BF09834887995C1A7412590EE3.description: Names the safety rules that apply to a physical activity practised alone or with others (e.g. wearing laced-up athletic shoes, removing jewellery)

B5698FE055724026B1953D8D6997D85A.description: Names the main rules of ethics in sport (e.g. following the rules of the game, refusing all forms of violence or cheating)

D9CBFD948713434FAB09DEAC2E01080D.description: Knowledge: Safe participation in physical activity and fair play

0ED4B346FF5A487CA0600B61E879D8C9.description: Uses techniques to relax after a physical effort or to manage his/her stress (e.g. controlled breathing, Jacobson method, yoga, mental imagery)

47134161BF5D471588BED8F6D33449AD.description: Uses tests to assess his/her cardiovascular endurance (e.g. 12-minute Cooper test, Léger shuttle run test)

963B43E1877E45F8B6A2800D189379F0.description: Uses tests to assess his/her strength and muscular endurance (e.g. partial curl-up test, push-up test)

1A590EA32B114BDD83BC68C81727C32D.description: Uses tests to assess his/her flexibility (e.g. sit-and-reach test)

518C01A920B34935B02F74D7ADB17309.description: Regular self-evaluation (cardiovascular capacity and other factors)

6CD2590803084C369FF1DE7FFD07DCD2.description: Trains while observing the periods of recovery during and after an activity (e.g. 1 : 1 = one period of work for one period of rest; 45 seconds of rest between two sets of muscle-building exercises)

6623961FE233433CB189AFB552C2838C.description: Applies basic training principles when doing muscular, cardiovascular and flexibility exercises (e.g. overload, specificity, progression)

6956D7698D844FD3A977433309BA928A.description: Takes into account his/her THR during a physical activity (e.g. during a 20-minute training session, taking the HR after 10 minutes to check one’s rating in relation to the THR zone)

51E16D1D791142168BEFA27AA34282A0.description: Paces him/herself during an activity of moderate to high intensity lasting from 20 to 30 consecutive minutes (e.g. starting slowly, breathing deeply)

86036C4B9C5A4AE9B159837655EB37EF.description: Calculates his/her THR based on his/her maximum heart rate (HRmax) (e.g. 70% of HRmax)

2314C418C2CA4BDB97CEE8A2F0C632E0.description: Uses the Borg perception scale to assess his/her level of effort and fatigue during or after a cardiovascular activity

FD3755A13BB449BA8B435334AA867ED9.description: Regular physical activity (characteristics of a session of physical activity

297074ABAD394A84A8EA75EFBA6471AE.description: Skills: Competency 3 – Adopts a healthy, active lifestyle

E203FD08DF2F4C78A1ADAA8E7E3C8DB0.description: Indicates strategies for managing the use of multimedia technology on a daily basis (e.g. 30 minutes at the computer = 30 minutes of physical activity)

FAC7853A2E2941F8AA74CB8964649E30.description: Names the effects of an excessive use of multimedia technology on his/her psychological or physical state (e.g. stiff muscles, isolation)

E40F11B1627E46AAA86602DA11D0029C.description: Indicates strategies for avoiding the consumption of harmful substances (e.g. getting information on the side effects of energy drinks, refusing them or not buying them)

0295B341F3D843208D548E9EA60B2755.description: Names the short- and long-term side effects (physical and psychological) of various substances (e.g. addiction, muscular hypertrophy, heart palpitations, sleep disturbances, increased stress)

AD75DF9B26BE4C3288B703A66B6423C3.description: Names substances that affect performance in sports and training (e.g. caffeine, energy drink, creatine)

074A6EAE63204127A1C8ABE808739A74.description: Effects of different substances on performance and training

01265699E80B4138BF73F366AF865A98.description: Names stressful situations that have an effect on his/her daily life (e.g. winning a competition, writing an exam)

51CF3EC5975C47FDAA045B8074246A9A.description: Stress prevention and management (positive or negative)

81FA74D6CF254426A2AF6985E92B4BD4.description: Indicates strategies for sleeping well (e.g. avoiding caffeine, going to bed at a regular time, using a relaxation technique)

B909DEAEDB2146F5984E828195CBD803.description: Names the effects of a good quality of sleep on his/her physical and psychological well-being (e.g. physical recovery, better concentration, increased motivation)

48DD788E899F4B9CA478EA5590BB5560.description: Names the benefits of personal hygiene when doing physical activities (e.g. feeling of well-being, peer acceptance)

F6652CE3A0EE47DAB1B0E5E199D1545D.description: Indicates strategies for making better food choices according to the intensity level of the physical activity (e.g. keeping granola bars in his/her sports bag, bringing along a bottle of water and juice, keeping a food journal)

92DA0241D608472996FD7779F8D4E5F6.description: Determines his/her needs before, during or after physical activity according to activity type and duration, and weather conditions (e.g. eating foods rich in carbohydrates before an activity, drinking 250 mL of water every 15 minutes during moderately intense physical activity, drinking a glass of chocolate milk after aerobic exercise)

19C16836D378484F8464BF7A30D183CA.description: Indicates strategies for developing or maintaining an active lifestyle (e.g. registering for a sports activity with friends, walking his/her dog, keeping an activity calendar, keeping track of his/her progress, using a pedometer)

8BA80FC36F9C4F0588F6141EE29AE423.description: Names the effects of a sedentary lifestyle (e.g. increased body weight, loss of muscle tone, increased risk of diabetes, isolation)

7E25891C4853440CB304328EA0205A62.description: Names the physical benefits of an active lifestyle (e.g. improved physical fitness, maintaining a balance between calorie intake and energy expenditure, increase in lean body mass, contribution to growth)

CE0D6060AAD04569B3AA77697A0C62E8.description: Names the psychological benefits of an active lifestyle (e.g. reduced fatigue and stress, sounder sleep, better concentration in class, pleasant emotions)

C87A69FC5FFD43DEBE863C82E6E23A6B.description: Explains the meaning of a sedentary lifestyle (e.g. engaging in passive activities such as watching television, surfing the Internet and playing video games several hours a day)

12397561130841B0BEF7055A9BCD0556.description: Explains the meaning of an active lifestyle (e.g. being physically active daily, taking the stairs, walking or bicycling to school)

3581EA87AABC45DFA6EE170E02F0E267.description: Describes a few training methods for improving strength and muscular endurance (e.g. Dynamic exercises involve lifting a submaximal load repeatedly and then lowering it.)

5E1DDE84FA0E41FAA2C550C9266F8DF9.description: Defines the concepts of strength and muscular endurance (e.g. Muscular endurance is the ability of a muscle or muscle group to contract submaximally in a repeated manner, usually involving 12 to 15 repetitions.)

74D86ED3AC6F4E7A93ED97DC2675B98B.description: Names physical activities that help improve strength and muscular endurance (e.g. weight training in a gym, body-building with elastics, training with a Swiss ball)

F44BF75FD302479CBCFC74858C4ED2FD.description: Describes a few training methods for improving flexibility (e.g. Static stretches are carried out slowly and require that the position be held for at least 15 seconds.)

44574CEA911D4FBF807A5BBECD1565C2.description: Defines the concept of flexibility (e.g. Flexibility is the ability to move a joint in accordance with its full range of motion without feeling any pain or stiffness.)

921F5609074A41A397F13E36F7A987E2.description: Names physical activities that help improve or maintain flexibility (e.g. yoga, tai-chi, stretching exercises)

05C95166F49745619DE98BC7450ACF46.description: Describes a few training methods for improving cardiovascular endurance (e.g. Circuit training is a sequence of muscular and cardiovascular exercises.)

21AD1D1B7A684854A88A94D3E9866777.description: Defines the concept of cardiovascular endurance (e.g. Cardiovascular endurance is the body’s ability to make the effort that is required in a moderately intense physical activity.)

DCBC0DB90BDB42D19657F2BAC006E0D1.description: Names physical activities that improve cardiovascular endurance (e.g. jogging, spinning, cross-country skiing)

46173372C0724211B1AA8999BE81F893.description: Components of heath-related fitness associated with the practice of physical activities

4116785C33AE4F16A0A4087EA719A885.description: Explains the body’s response to exercise by making connections with the different systems (e.g. Perspiration helps regulate body temperature.)

2360410EB7CE43A09CC26A01EDCFACC8.description: In simple terms or using a diagram, explains the main systems involved in physical activity (e.g. The cardiovascular system carries oxygen and nutrients to the muscles in accordance with the physical effort involved.)

0DA3F408F6B24D96AC21AC59D9FB515D.description: Names the main components of the systems involved in carrying out physical activities (cardiovascular, respiratory and muscular systems) (e.g. heart, lungs, abdominals)

0B9941F5394A49FF9946116F6C8172F0.description: Knowledge: Competency 3 – Adopts a healthy, active lifestyle

A44EA2B52985429B94D2435652818814.description: Moves efficiently in relation to the target or goal to be protected, teammates, opponents and the object

67D4A56C1C07439AA1F22CCDB059F94E.description: Protects own team’s target or goal (e.g. blocking a shot on goal, closely guarding the carrier to impede an attack on the goal)

AA69313E17A64A25A9CD5518FCFD264B.description: Uses the space available (e.g. moving into the available space to receive a pass)

876035BFEB074EDD8BE0AB2BF2E15C05.description: Gets back on defence (e.g. getting back quickly to defend his/her territory)

1EDB30F0B0E4434B96045B115184CF78.description: Action rules relating to the territory

09589977593D4279B3EAEBDF550D443F.description: with a feint (e.g. faking a catch)

53A99B37AD27471098A655908B11D16F.description: with a change of direction (e.g. following a pattern in football)

7DD24BBBBB464E4A87F13D3BF8CE1896.description: with a change of speed (e.g. running faster to elude the opponent)

8F177379EFDE4562A29ED98ACFDDF85B.description: Gets free from the opponent by moving away

BE05A734544D4B2C8195F342B7F9FC96.description: by staying close to the noncarrier while protecting the passing lane and the target (e.g. “challenging” in basketball)

9C294CC461634E88AB50691673FD6D56.description: by positioning him/herself between the noncarrier and the target to impede the offensive team’s progress

CAA820344F6C48389237E32D7530530A.description: by preventing him/her from receiving the object

9ADDCF3CCBA84531BB9B5F0CDEB5BE83.description: Guards the carrier to prevent him/her from attacking the target, passing the object to a teammate or moving forward (e.g. pressuring the carrier)

424952F0088A4EB0A25EEB0D1A9CC4CB.description: Moves away from the carrier, at a distance that will help advance or move the object (e.g. avoiding clusters)

5DD77C05DB18477B9E257C922607CC9C.description: Action rules related to a partner or an opponent

77A095A8839E47E9B71A284E12AA98AA.description: Interferes with the object’s progress (e.g. standing in the object’s path to intercept it, blocking a throw)

5127794295814002A6E7BBB4D69229E6.description: Counterattacks (e.g. recovering the object and heading toward the target, quickly resuming the attack following a defensive action)

51CCAF3ADA0947E4A40C275BEC345ADE.description: Recovers the object (e.g. recovering a loose object, recovering the ball on the rebound)

D8DB20B1F0F847698C43C0C69478221C.description: . in relation to teammates or opponents

3066A291A3B84994B5AF6B2DDEC3445B.description: Attacks the opponent’s target by throwing or striking the object

8A431106D072412C87838E0D544B0482.description: Keeps the object in play, moving from the offensive zone toward the defensive zone, while varying his/her direction and speed (e.g. quickly passing to an unguarded player who is in the best position, moving with the object toward an open space)

65B0A0CEAF2E4CA8950B298D574CE91F.description: Moves the object toward the opponent’s target (e.g. passing to the player in the best position relative to the target, moving with the object toward the target)

9FCDD2FC0F484BDB8B612317338CF78F.description: Action rules related to the object

8C57486B981D4F2D9D51C2F54A3A6228.description: Action rules in group activities in a common space (e.g. hot potato, basketball, soccer, ultimate Frisbee)

0983E1B044A4489CA23A0114A4AB01D1.description: Counterattacks the opposing team (replying) (e.g. in volleyball, performing a block with a partner)

BF0E4FE2EE9C413FA205C0650D80D699.description: Attacks spaces left open by the opponent (e.g. directing a smash toward an open space)

B5A2649B88B842B9B8E0532E7DE585DF.description: Uses the full width and depth of the playing field by varying the direction and speed of the object and using different types of throws (e.g. aiming for the lines or the backcourt)

4DFC4D293BC741B5849EDE9CAD882CD1.description: Moves the object toward the opponent’s territory (e.g. returning the ball to the passer)

E532C7E9702E4512961B1D0E6551D618.description: Keeps the object moving in his/her territory (e.g. receiving the ball high in the air to keep it on one’s side of the net)

CEFE685D51A34947A92BF8A0A91EFEC9.description: Attacks the other team’s target (e.g. serving in volleyball)

E046CFC17F6E48908956559E94477039.description: Action rules related to attacking the opposing team’s territory

098C75360CE84D15B32CB5419E59CECF.description: Protects his/her territory by positioning him/herself in relation to the opponent, partners and the object (e.g. in volleyball, playing a supporting role, adopting a defensive “ W ” formation when receiving a serve)

5809BE1742954C5FA2CFC21464CE562C.description: Recovers the object by positioning him/herself or by moving toward the point where the object will fall (e.g. receiving a serve in volleyball, retrieving a lost ball)

E201EEC3D3AC45EB920EFAF3624A2EA5.description: Action rules related to protecting his/her territory

1F157002FBBE4088A83D17EA1FF3FAD3.description: Action rules in cooperative activities in separate spaces (e.g. volleyball, sepak takraw

3BBF16CC7A2243DCAEA537B96B712BA4.description: Catches the opponent wrong-footed by attacking him/her in the direction opposite to which he/she is moving (e.g. in badminton, performing a second drop shot right after the first)

E66EA763B3C94D66B1C8C040BFC7EED7.description: Feints in order to mislead the opponent (e.g. in badminton, simulating a smash and then performing a drop shot)

8D60A256CA1D4D1DBBE08CBB2C40DB67.description: Attacks at opportune moments (e.g. in badminton, executing a smash when the opponent is off-balance)

3D6C841B03DE437C83CEEB67274F6FAC.description: Uses the appropriate space to better attack the opponent or his/her territory (e.g. in tennis, returning to the strategic centre of the court)

21121792B0734CA5BF2BD47B14A80156.description: Quickly recovers the object in order to continue the rally (e.g. in tennis, moving quickly toward the spot where the ball will fall in order to hit it back over the net)

E28D40B219F24EFF9101AD3862694808.description: Uses the width and length of the playing surface (e.g. using different shots to force the opponent to move)

33EE85FCB84F4BA39C95F3083329C30D.description: Action rules in duelling activities (e.g. badminton, tennis, fencing, 1 against 1 in basketball)

1651F87F0F6B4D43A2F2F30AD09E1E83.description: Applies various defensive action rules in a combat activity, such as maintaining his/her balance, reacting to the opponent’s actions, moving in relation to the available space and to the opponent (e.g. in wrestling, widening one’s stance and dodging by moving one’s trunk to the left)

C10B306CF82144F78526CF18B868692C.description: Applies various offensive action rules in a combat activity, such as throwing the opponent off balance, attacking an opponent who is off balance, moving in relation to the available space and to the opponent, varying force, speed and direction, and feinting (e.g. in back-to-back wrestling, pushing or pulling the opponent to get him/her off the mat)

38E3C8F617024EEDB8731838D6FAE5EB.description: Action rules in combat activities (e.g. wrestling, judo, self-defense, back-to-back wrestling)

D0183F8D033A435D806C52D971926051.description: Varies force, speed and direction of movements or movement skills in relation to those of teammate(s) (e.g. adjusting one’s speed when receiving the baton during a relay race, paddling at different speeds depending on a partner's speed)

6A03D15BC36640D79629F1D461222906.description: Positions him/herself or moves away in relation to teammate(s) (e.g. building pyramids, negotiating obstacles along a path in cooperation with a partner)

572631E9EAA540598F30B4AA81F55183.description: Uses several of the movement skills learned in individual physical activities (e.g. serving in badminton, throwing a ball at the basket)

2A9A1DE3C9CA46B1802780724D413A83.description: Uses several of the movement skills learned in individual physical activities (e.g. pivoting so that the body will face the centre of the playing field)

3FF8E780D0B44EB5A404FE0732BCAF88.description: Uses several of the mouvement skills learned in individual physical activities (e.g. running back to the defensive zone)

8476E11C05C44249ADE1619F2C454240.description: Plays his/her role in the game or activity in accordance with the established strategy or plan of action (e.g. forward, noncarrier, goal keeper)

6EFC07C0B62C4586935A3521C362D231.description: Chooses a supporting role and plays it when preparing a plan and during the activity (e.g. team leader, referee, scorer)

0C78935C9A1F42F4A934A8E1DE6416BE.description: Adapts his/her actions to those of one or more partners according to different synchronization modes (e.g. in unison [rowing at the same time as one’s partner], in succession [doing the wave])

B1761D0F20D94745956C8841EE6781B3.description: Receives an object from his/her partners or opponents by taking into account its speed and direction (e.g. catching a popfly in baseball, receiving a serve in volleyball)

7D735E57BA4442E291E062EB2C8D0389.description: Throws an object by taking into account the speed and direction of his/her partners or opponents (e.g. in football, passing the ball to a teammate in motion)

89C425A872914E0E992F1D3808A7213D.description: Communicates various misleading messages appropriate to the activity (e.g. carrying out a body feint, faking a pass to the right and then passing to the left)

F8D29F739D15419496B8F0A8DA511CCC.description: Recognizes messages (e.g. in basketball, seeing an unguarded player asking for the ball)

0E4ECD4BCA68489E9471E435F0294385.description: Communicates clear messages appropriate to the activity (e.g. calling for a pass in soccer, clapping hands, presenting a target as a way of calling for the object)

DB181B947E214C66AA62E0BEF1E027D0.description: Skills: Competency 2 – Interacts with others in different physical activity settings

E4E649F66A3E4B2DA609D6CC08EBF242.description: Names the technical aspects of performing different movement skills pertaining to the physical activity performed

41C295423EFB4652859B73054FD34347.description: Technical aspects of movement related to activities

83A649728D9A43579A655530B9A83532.description: Knowledge: Competency 2 – Interacts with others in different physical activity settings

6F4B378A201D457ABA2CB9AAA948B344.description: Catches an object with an implement (e.g. catching with an intercross stick, catching a spool with the string in diabolo, blocking or deflecting a shot on goal in hockey)

FA2EF54201434E8F8D4CA67C14FA50D6.description: Catches an object without an implement (e.g. catching a ball thrown against a wall, blocking or deflecting a shot on goal in team handball)

BDAB4936EE1242CBAD7225AE3D442285.description: Catches a variety of objects, applying an appropriate technique (e.g. watching the object, intercepting the object, slowing down the object and bringing it toward oneself in order to be ready to resume play)

7970123CAA75463AAA1496ED5F79D1A7.description: Receiving objects with or without an implement

7A2A506A29F44BB7AEDB2BCA2D50C6CB.description: Strikes a moving object (e.g. hitting a baseball, kicking the ball upon reception or a smash in volleyball)

D0DF2FCAD54245BC8B899C9621D102D1.description: Strikes an immobile object (e.g. golf stroke, field-goal kick, slap shot in hockey skills competition)

D91C5D79378D45CFA709307A5219C0A3.description: Strikes objects in various ways, with or without an implement, applying an appropriate technique (e.g. stable position facing the target, weight transfer, trunk rotation, eyes focused on the object to be struck)

73A8ED9F81054C87908A93152B64E4B9.description: Throws an object using an implement (e.g. throwing in intercross)

B20FEBE4CB5B41FBA87AF6D04AA4C01E.description: Throws an object overhand (e.g. throwing a basketball, throwing a javelin, passing in flag-football)

6E655B29F7354195B29AD060DAC0C3D0.description: Throws an object sideways (e.g. throwing a Frisbee, a disk)

A237C7FB52DC43C4A54B71BF93A52F09.description: Throws an object with two hands (e.g., throw-in and chest pass in soccer)

86D62B41684649B3AF32DBFAE36FB1E9.description: Throws an object underhand (e.g. throwing a softball, bowling)

AB12BB3DDB354D368CFA53A278F92513.description: Throws a variety of objects, applying an appropriate technique (e.g. keeping the eyes on the target, cocking the arm, bringing the opposite leg toward the target, transferring the weight)

2FF5A69AAE034455989FD632F3394218.description: Projecting objects with or without an implement (e.g. in skill-based or single-action activities)

844DDCBB50214DECB6E5B79871C19BF8.description: Handles an object using an implement on the spot, while moving or through obstacles (e.g. controlling a ball with a broom)

FBF010D260144F02A70A6D0A783ED6E2.description: Performs a variety of object-handling actions with implements, applying an appropriate technique (e.g. holding the stick with both hands, not focusing too intently on the object)

B75A313C031E402FAE790381E12BA7C9.description: Handles several objects at the same time on the spot, while moving or on fixed or moving apparatus (e.g. juggling three balls in a cascade pattern or in columns on a cylinder, dribbling two balls)

7E97D8D08AE343F287BAC36AA68C608F.description: Handles an object with the dominant or non-dominant foot on the spot, while moving or through obstacles (e.g. dribbling a soccer ball between cones and bowling pins, bouncing an aki ball off different parts of the body)

C5155E5DA58E446E863DCAF1D09C0053.description: Handles an object with the dominant or non-dominant hand, on the spot, while moving or through obstacles (e.g. figure 8 dribble)

B35F77D3519146A5ACB39C773A3C601B.description: Performs a variety of object-handling actions, applying an appropriate technique (e.g. while dribbling, absorbing the force of the ball rather than simply hitting it, keeping the head up)

6BCA1B84462D4896AAFC3DE24AD53469.description: Handling objects with or without an implement (e.g. in skill-based or single-action activities)

4DE272FFCBA943DC8EE07C5468EC9686.description: Masters turning on his/her own axis on the floor, in the air or on apparatus, applying an appropriate technique (e.g. bringing the arms closer to the body to increase rotational speed)

434E4B440A7F4CE4B6C1F9DC0F913DD6.description: Maintains complex postures, applying an appropriate technique (e.g. forming a triangle with the hands and head to successfully perform a headstand)

8E0A49F4ACD24F5E9C10CE2B62624ECF.description: Postures and rotations (e.g. in technical/artistic activities)

E86EB95DF5384412B6CA61864A07EA28.description: Performs complex rotations on the floor or in the air, applying an appropriate technique such as cartwheel, round-off, forward or backward roll, turn and half-turn on the floor or from a box (e.g. keeping the body perpendicular to the floor during a cartwheel)

531B4947348A4EFF8DDEF7ADF8CB5CFE.description: Running jumps such as the long jump, high jump and triple jump (e.g. accelerating gradually during a run-up, lowering the centre of gravity before pushing off, blocking with the take-off leg)

A01BFB71C8F34C2F8317EE77CAFAAB0B.description: Standing jumps such as the squat jump, half-turn jump, scissor jump and long jump (e.g. in a standing jump, swinging the arms for more momentum; in rope jumping, adopting a stable position at the outset and slightly flexing the knees to gain momentum)

561CAAD30DD04409B748A42E79F1B059.description: Performs different types of jumps, applying an appropriate technique

C1AF20B886F44F6A801620407ACFE452.description: Goes up, goes down, changes direction, goes around, goes over, climbs and brakes by applying an appropriate technique given the environmental constraints (e.g. along adventure trails, approaching the uphill sections with toes pointed, the top half of the body learning forward while shortening one's stride)

CF7DA9A5D1E144E48AE8362D3AE4B85B.description: Long-distance and middle-distance running (e.g. pointing the toes forward and using the arms throughout the race)

2EE9CC36332445D28963B5D8971DBB47.description: Sprinting (e.g. lengthening the stride, raising the knee, swinging arms back and forth, with elbows held at 90 degrees at all times)

374AC4EF156A401BAFA5D143F21BC257.description: Runs while applying a technique appropriate to the duration of the activity or the distance involved

101BBCF477EB4798AFB9F9222EAE6182.description: Walks while applying a technique appropriate to the duration of the activity or the distance involved (e.g. flexing arms, shortening strides in order to increase the pace during a hike)

0C9A2274A58F48C2860F6508F4395378.description: Synchronizes his/her actions according to a rhythm (e.g. synchronizing breathing with arm movements when doing the crawl, performing a routine to music, synchronizing successive jumps in a hurdle race)

6831908A7F6448C8840B83DAAF095A72.description: Receives an object by moving to the point where the object will fall (e.g. In juggling or rhythmic gymnastics, the entire body or the arms must be moved to recover an object.)

578A45F66E43466498FA9229ADF7AE98.description: Throws an object to attain a moving target

48F8764BB4CE40CA935ADCC95F1A3ADA.description: Applies principles for coordinating his/her movements when carrying out various actions (e.g. In a javelin throw, joints must be used in the correct order, starting with the approach run and followed by the arm being cocked so that all the power in the shoulder can be harnessed.)

61DAC1A190CE4106B902822C00EC7E52.description: Applies principles for maintaining or restoring his/her balance when performing various movements (e.g. In a tight turn while skiing or cycling, the centre of gravity must be shifted toward the inside; in the shot put, the weight is transferred from the back foot to the front foot and balance is re-established when the back foot is brought forward.)

AE72D3704593487DBB2443B4A000DDA3.description: Applies principles for maintaining his/her balance in various postures (e.g. In a complex posture on hands or feet, one’s base should be widened to maintain balance.)

DB2082D1D8A845DB84CB6A60DC7DCBBB.description: Skills: Competency 1 – Performs movement skills in different physical activity settings

1F29B32FF9544C638C2585DD2AFE62B4.description: Names the technical aspects of movement related to the execution of various movement skills, depending on the physical activity performed

0A7CAD2E90D441089E2DF8A189A6133F.description: Technical aspects of movement related to activities

E8C5508555FF403B91C942AB1133C0C2.description: Names the possible impact of menstruation on physical activities (e.g. temporary anemia, abdominal cramps that make it difficult to walk for long periods)

8B953BEC07834BF6BAB81A6F848D9271.description: Identifies a few morphological changes that occur during growth and that affect coordination and relative strength (e.g. A growth spurt and longer segments can temporarily affect coordination.)

58222D66FBFE4819AA0ED33AEA2D1416.description: Identifies a few motor changes that occur during development and that affect how certain physical activities are carried out (e.g. decreased coordination, decreased flexibility)

7CF40F8AC0DE41A7A06B7B4D65A83D17.description: Describes the appropriate position of his/her body or body parts in relation to an object, an implement or a space (territory) (e.g. The height of the lead leg should be adjusted with respect to the hurdle.)

BBD1DE98CCF0412D90B6F145A94C99EA.description: Describes the adjustments to be made to the speed of movement or travel according to the constraints of the activity (e.g. In cross-country skiing, balance is maintained while going downhill by braking to adjust one’s speed; in cycling, balance is maintained by pedalling fast enough.)

936F7DA13B6E4BF0B057367357305572.description: Describes the position of his/her segments or the adjustments needed to perform a given movement skill (in a stable position or in motion) (e.g. For wall push-ups, hands are placed shoulder width apart and the back is kept straight; for the back crawl, the head should remain close to the surface of the water so that a hydrodynamic position can be maintained.)

ABBA26498E0B4369BE0E6DFDDBE1DCA6.description: Explains the role of stabilizing and agonist muscles (flexor, extensor, rotator, abductor, adductor) (e.g. The dorsal and abdominal muscles play a role in posture and they contract simultaneously. When the forearm is flexed, the agonist biceps contract to produce movement.)

13134A9F4C9C49BDA897B01179D09F34.description: Explains the main role of the ligaments (e.g. The ligaments are like elastics that keep the joints stable.)

72482D30185F40EBBA34984216D470E6.description: Names the joints, bones and main muscles involved in the execution of a given movement skill (e.g. The shoulder, elbow, wrist and triceps are involved in throwing an object.)

2EC2079ABA884ACB94B9147134D686AF.description: Knowledge: Competency 1 – Performs movement skills in different physical activity settings
